huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION: This unit is a General Season hunt unit and is not managed to be a trophy unit but every year a few really nice bucks are taken.  The Pine Valley Unit is 90% public land, but hunters should be aware of the private lands and learn the boundaries.  Deer on the Archery hunt are spread out across their summer ranges deer densities are higher in some areas than they are in other.  Some high deer density areas also have higher numbers of hunters and can result in some hunter crowding. Please be aware of other hunters and be courteous. Day time temperatures during the archery hunt can still reach into the low 90’s.  On years with good monsoonal moisture the deer may be spread out more across their range.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: It can be very hot during this season.  Please be prepared with plenty of water.  Make sure friends and family know where you area going and when you will return.  Be aware of rattle snakes!
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightening, snow, wind and heat.  Early fall snow storms occur regularly in this area during this hunt.  Be prepared for dry or muddy conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 15.4~19500~15500~18–20~19.4~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Migration Patterns: Many of the deer on this unit migrate down in elevation beginning in the second or third week of October. Dry or wet conditions will dictate where you can find deer during the hunting seasons. Migration should not be a factor on this hunt.

Mule Deer rut: The mule deer rut usually runs from mid Nov.-mid Dec. So it does not affect this hunt.

Recommended areas to hunt: The Pine Valley Unit has a healthy deer population. Deer densities are high in good deer habitat. Expect to see several bucks each day. To increase your chances of seeing deer it is best to find water in good deer habitat. There are several livestock tanks, springs and guzzlers in this semi-desert area.
Some good areas to hunt are the following:
Bull Valley Mountains – Forest Service and small tracts of private land South and West of Enterprise. This area is very accessible by vehicles. Deer densities decrease as you move further west towards the Nevada state line. Hunting is best in oak brush and service berry near water sources.
Bumblebee Mtn. – BLM, USFS, and SITLA SW of Cedar City. The higher elevation areas in the oak brush best for locating deer. Access is limited to a few main roads and ATV trails. Hunters will do better if they get out and do some hiking and spotting deer.
Paradise and Pine Valley Wilderness – Forest Service land from Pace Draw NW of New Harmony to the south face of the Pine Valley Mtn. This area is remote and has little to no vehicle access. There are several foot and horse trails into the area. Some access points are the Anderson and Comanche trail head in the New Harmony area, The Grants Ranch trail head between New Harmony and Pinto, The Paradise trail head near Pinto, The Mill Canyon and Water Canyon trail heads south of the Town of Pine Valley in Grass Valley, The Whipple and Forsyth trail heads in Pine Valley. The further you are willing to hike in the better the hunting may become.
Atchison and Harrison Peak – Forest Service land Between Mountain Meadow and Grass Valley. Mostly sagebrush and serviceberry habitat with some scattered pinion and juniper. This area has limited access and with a few ATV trails. Hiking in a ½ mile plus from the roads will increase success in finding the bucks.

huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: Voluntary: The DWR conducts random surveys for all general season hunts. You may be contacted via phone to participate in this survey.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: Land Ownership: Public, Private, State Trust Lands (SITLA). The public lands are Bureau of Land Management (BLM) and Dixie National Forest managed out of the Cedar City and St. George Field Offices, respectively. Ninety percent of the deer habitat is on public lands. There is one CWMU on the unit. The New Harmony CWMU is for deer and turkey. Information on maps can be found at: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/res/utah_public_room/maps.print.html http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/dixie/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO:
There are BLM and USFS campgrounds on the unit. Baker Dam campground for BLM lands is near Veyo. Some campgrounds on USFS land are Oak Grove, Honeycomb Rocks, and Pine Valley reservoir. Please direct all questions regarding campground availability and other camping questions to the BLM and the USFS. Cedar City and St. George BLM website: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/cedar_city/recreation.html
St. George Forest Service website: http://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/dixie/recreation/ohv
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Information on maps can be found at: http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/res/utah_public_room/maps.print.html http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/dixie/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS: Stay on existing roads and trails. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and the Dixie National Forest and are covered on their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to BLM and USFS. http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/moab/recreation/motorized_routes/ohv_designations.html http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/st__george/recreation/motorized_recreation.html http://www.fs.usda.gov/activity/dixie/recreation/ohv
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES: The Shivwit Piute Tribe owns a large property west of Ivins.  This is primarily on deer winter range and would only be a factor during the any weapon deer hunt.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Iron and Washington counties—Boundary begins at the Utah-Arizona state line and I-15; north on I-15 to SR-56; west on SR-56 to the Lund highway; northwest on this highway to Lund and the Union Pacific railroad tracks; southwest along these tracks to the Utah-Nevada state line; south on this state line to the Utah-Arizona state line; east on this state line to I-15. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LANDS WITHIN THIS BOUNDARY. Excludes all CWMUs. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Caliente, Cedar City, Clover Mountains, Saint George. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.
